content: Compared to the prior year, revenue grew 7% as the elimination of fee waivers and the favorable impact from higher interest rates more than offset the significant headwind from weaker equity and fixed income markets, asset outflows and unfavorable currency movements. Within Asset Servicing, custody and fund administration fees were $407 million, down 12% year-over-year and down 6% sequentially. Assets under custody and administration for Asset Servicing clients were $12 trillion at quarter end, down 19% year-over-year and down 7% sequentially. Assets under management for our wealth management clients were $336 billion at quarter end, down 10% year-over-year and down 5% on a sequential basis. Your line is open. Your line is open. One moment for next question. Your line is open. One moment for next question. Your line is open. One moment for next question. Your line is open. Your line is open. Your line is open. They're driven by transaction volumes and account-level fees or flat fees of the asset-sensitive fees, that's 60%, about 75% operate on a month lag and about 25% on a quarter lag. Your line is open. One moment for next question. Your line is open. Your line is open. How does that compare to the last tightening cycle is 80% at this point, normal or similar, I should say, not normal -- and second, if rates continue to go higher let's say, another 75 to 100 basis points, will the incremental beta approach 100%.?
